'''PRISM''' is a [[code name]] for a program under which the [[United States]] [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) collects internet communications from various U.S. internet companies.<ref name="WaPo1">{{cite news| author = [[Barton Gellman|Gellman, Barton]]; [[Laura Poitras|Poitras, Laura]] | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/us-intelligence-mining-data-from-nine-us-internet-companies-in-broad-secret-program/2013/06/06/3a0c0da8-cebf-11e2-8845-d970ccb04497_story.html | title = US Intelligence Mining Data from Nine U.S. Internet Companies in Broad Secret Program |work=[[The Washington Post]] | date = June 6, 2013 |accessdate=June 15, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Greenwald1" /><ref name="apbraun061513">{{cite news|last=Braun|first=Stephen|last2=Flaherty|first2=Anne|last3=Gillum|first3=Jack|last4=Apuzzo|first4=Matt|title=Secret to PRISM Program: Even Bigger Data Seizures|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/secret-prism-success-even-bigger-data-seizure|work = Associated Press |date=June 15, 2013 |accessdate=June 18, 2013}}</ref><!--{{#tag:ref|Multiple technology writers have asserted that the term "PRISM" refers to the computer systems tool that is used to gather intelligence rather than to the surveillance program itself, consistent with statements from U.S. government sources.<ref name=Cnet-McCullagh>{{cite news|author = [[Declan McCullagh|McCullagh, Declan]] |title=No Evidence of NSA's 'Direct Access' to Tech Companies{{spaced ndash}} Sources Challenge Reports Alleging National Security Agency Is 'Tapping Directly into the Central Servers'{{spaced ndash}} Instead, They Say, the Spy Agency Is Obtaining Orders under Process Created by Congress|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13578_3-57588337-38/no-evidence-of-nsas-direct-access-to-tech-companies/ |accessdate=June 15, 2013| publisher = [[CNET]] |date=June 7, 2013}}</ref> [[Marc Ambinder]], the co-author of a forthcoming book on national security and secrecy, described PRISM as "a kick-ass [[graphical user interface|GUI]] that allows an analyst to look at, collate, monitor, and cross-check different data types provided to the NSA from internet companies located inside the United States."<ref>Ambinder, Marc (June 7, 2013). [http://theweek.com/article/index/245360/solving-the-mystery-of-prism "Solving the Mystery of PRISM"]. ''The Compass'' (blog of ''[[The Week]]''). Retrieved June 18, 2013.</ref> |group = "Notes"}}--> The program is also known by the [[SIGINT Activity Designator|SIGAD]] {{nowrap|US-984XN}}.<ref>{{cite web | author = Chappell, Bill | url = https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2013/06/06/189321612/nsa-reportedly-mines-servers-of-u-s-internet-firms-for-data |title=NSA Reportedly Mines Servers of US Internet Firms for Data | publisher=''The Two-Way'' (blog of [[NPR]]) | date=June 6, 2013 |accessdate=June 15, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | author = Staf | url = http://www.zdnet.com/prism-heres-how-the-nsa-wiretapped-the-internet-7000016565/ |title=PRISM: Here's How the NSA Wiretapped the Internet | publisher=[[ZDNet]] |date=June 8, 2013 |accessdate=June 15, 2013}}</ref> PRISM collects stored internet communications based on demands made to internet companies such as [[Google Inc.]] under Section 702 of the [[FISA Amendments Act of 2008]] to turn over any data that match court-approved search terms.<ref>{{cite news|title=NSA infiltrates links to Yahoo, Google data centers worldwide, Snowden documents say|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-infiltrates-links-to-yahoo-google-data-centers-worldwide-snowden-documents-say/2013/10/30/e51d661e-4166-11e3-8b74-d89d714ca4dd_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=30 October 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani |lastauthoramp=yes }}</ref> The NSA can use these PRISM requests to target communications that were encrypted when they traveled across the [[internet backbone]], to focus on stored data that telecommunication filtering systems discarded earlier,<ref name="WSJ20130821">{{cite news|title=New Details Show Broader NSA Surveillance Reach - Programs Cover 75% of Nation's Traffic, Can Snare Emails|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324108204579022874091732470?mod=WSJEurope_hpp_LEFTTopStories|accessdate=August 21, 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=20 August 2013|author1=Siobhan Gorman |author2=Jennifer Valentiono-Devries |lastauthoramp=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Graphic: How the NSA Scours Internet Traffic in the U.S. |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324108204579022874091732470?mod=WSJEurope_hpp_LEFTTopStories#project%3DNSA0820%26articleTabs%3Dinteractive |accessdate=August 21, 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=20 August 2013}}</ref> and to get data that is easier to handle, among other things.<ref>{{cite news|title=What You Need to Know on New Details of NSA Spying|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324108204579025222244858490?mod=WSJEurope_hpp_LEFTTopStories|accessdate=August 21, 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=20 August 2013|author1=Jennifer Valentiono-Devries |author2=Siobhan Gorman |lastauthoramp=yes }}</ref>
PRISM began in 2007 in the wake of the passage of the [[Protect America Act]] under the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush Administration]].<ref>Lee, Timothy B. (June 6, 2013). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2013/06/06/how-congress-unknowingly-legalized-prism-in-2007/ "How Congress Unknowingly Legalized PRISM in 2007"]. ''Wonkblog'' (blog of ''[[The Washington Post]]''). Retrieved July 4, 2013.</ref><ref>Johnson, Luke (July 1, 2013). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/01/george-bush-prism_n_3528249.html "George W. Bush Defends PRISM: 'I Put That Program in Place to Protect the Country'"]. ''[[The Huffington Post]]''. Retrieved July 4, 2013.</ref> The program is operated under the supervision of the [[United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court|U.S. Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court]] (FISA Court, or FISC) pursuant to the [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act]] (FISA).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dni.gov/files/documents/Facts%20on%20the%20Collection%20of%20Intelligence%20Pursuant%20to%20Section%20702.pdf | title =Facts on the Collection of Intelligence Pursuant to Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act | author =''[[Office of the Director of National Intelligence]]'' | publisher =dni.gov | date =June 8, 2013}}</ref> Its existence was [[news leak|leaked]] six years later by NSA contractor [[Edward Snowden]], who warned that the extent of mass data collection was far greater than the public knew and included what he characterized as "dangerous" and "criminal" activities.<ref name="ibtimes 17 june">Mezzofiore, Gianluca (June 17, 2013). [http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/479709/20130617/nsa-whistleblower-edward-snowden.htm "NSA Whistleblower Edward Snowden: Washington Snoopers Are Criminals"]. ''[[International Business Times]]''. Retrieved June 30, 2013.</ref> The disclosures were published by ''[[The Guardian]]'' and ''[[The Washington Post]]'' on June 6, 2013. Subsequent documents have demonstrated a financial arrangement between the NSA's [[Special Source Operations]] division (SSO) and PRISM partners in the millions of dollars.<ref name=Guardian20130823>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/23/nsa-prism-costs-tech-companies-paid|title=NSA paid millions to cover Prism compliance costs for tech companies|author=MacAskill, Ewan|date=August 23, 2013|accessdate=August 27, 2013}}</ref>
Documents indicate that PRISM is "the number one source of raw intelligence used for NSA analytic reports", and it accounts for 91% of the NSA's internet traffic acquired under [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act|FISA]] section 702 authority."<ref name="wp_slides" /><ref name="FiscPrivacyRuling2011">{{cite web|url=https://www.eff.org/sites/default/files/filenode/fisc_opinion_-_unconstitutional_surveillance_0.pdf|page=71|date=October 3, 2011|author=John D Bates|title=[redacted]}}</ref> The leaked information came to light one day after the revelation that the FISA Court had been ordering a subsidiary of telecommunications company [[Verizon Communications]] to turn over to the NSA logs tracking all of its customers' telephone calls.<ref name="nytsavage060613" /><ref name="nsaphones">{{cite news| author=[[Glenn Greenwald|Greenwald, Glenn]]| title = NSA Collecting Phone Records of Millions of Verizon Customers Daily – Top Secret Court Order Requiring Verizon to Hand Over All Call Data Shows Scale of Domestic Surveillance under Obama| url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/06/nsa-phone-records-verizon-court-order | work=[[The Guardian]]| date=June 5, 2013 |accessdate=June 15, 2013}}</ref>
U.S. government officials have disputed some aspects of the ''Guardian'' and ''Washington Post'' stories and have defended the program by asserting it cannot be used on domestic targets without a [[search warrant|warrant]], that it has helped to prevent acts of [[terrorism]], and that it receives independent oversight from the federal government's [[U.S. Executive Branch#Executive branch|executive]], [[U.S. Executive Branch#Judicial branch|judicial]] and [[U.S. Executive Branch#Legislative branch|legislative]] branches.<ref name="Intelligence">{{Cite news| author = Staff | url = https://news.yahoo.com/intelligence-chief-blasts-nsa-leaks-declassifies-details-phone-025804881.html | title=Intelligence Chief Blasts NSA Leaks, Declassifies Some Details about Phone Program Limits | publisher = Associated Press (via ''[[The Washington Post]]'') |accessdate=June 15, 2013 | date = June 6, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | first = Shira | last = Ovide | date = June 8, 2013 | url = https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887324299104578533802289432458 | title = U.S. Official Releases Details of Prism Program | work = [[The Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=June 15, 2013}}</ref> On June 19, 2013, U.S. President [[Barack Obama]], during a visit to Germany, stated that the NSA's data gathering practices constitute "a circumscribed, narrow system directed at us being able to protect our people."<ref name="cbsberlin">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-250_162-57590025/obama-defends-narrow-surveillance-programs/|title=Obama Defends 'Narrow' Surveillance Programs|publisher=[[CBS News]] |first=Lucy|last=Madison|date=June 19, 2013 |accessdate=June 30, 2013}}</ref>
== Media disclosure of PRISM == {{see also|Global surveillance disclosure}}
PRISM was publicly revealed when classified documents about the program were leaked to journalists of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and ''[[The Guardian]]'' by [[Edward Snowden]]{{spaced ndash}} at the time an NSA contractor{{spaced ndash}} during a visit to [[Hong Kong]].<ref name="WaPo1" /><ref name="Greenwald1" /> The leaked documents included 41 [[Microsoft PowerPoint|PowerPoint slides]], four of which were published in news articles.<ref name="WaPo1" /><ref name="Greenwald1" />
The documents identified several technology companies as participants in the PRISM program, including [[Microsoft]] in 2007, [[Yahoo!]] in 2008, [[Google]] in 2009, [[Facebook]] in 2009, [[Paltalk]] in 2009, [[YouTube]] in 2010, [[AOL]] in 2011, [[Skype]] in 2011 and [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] in 2012.<ref name="usa1">{{cite news|author1=Johnson, Kevin |author2=Martin, Scott |author3=O'Donnell, Jayne |author4=Winter, Michael | title=Reports: NSA Siphons Data from 9 Major Net Firms|url = https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2013/06/06/nsa-surveillance-internet-companies/2398345/|accessdate=June 6, 2013|work=USA Today|date=June 15, 2013}}</ref> The speaker's notes in the briefing document reviewed by ''The Washington Post'' indicated that "98 percent of PRISM production is based on Yahoo, Google, and Microsoft".<ref name="WaPo1" />
The slide presentation stated that much of the world's electronic communications pass through the U.S., because electronic communications data tend to follow the least expensive route rather than the most physically direct route, and the bulk of the world's internet infrastructure is based in the United States.<ref name="wp_slides" /> The presentation noted that these facts provide United States intelligence analysts with opportunities for intercepting the communications of foreign targets as their electronic data pass into or through the United States.<ref name="Greenwald1" /><ref name="wp_slides" />
Snowden's subsequent disclosures included statements that government agencies such as the [[United Kingdom]]'s [[Government Communications Headquarters|GCHQ]] also undertook mass interception and tracking of internet and communications data<ref>MacAskill, Ewen; Borger, Julian; Hopkins, Nick; [[Nick Davies|Davies, Nick]]; Ball, James (June 21, 2013). [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/jun/21/gchq-cables-secret-world-communications-nsa "GCHQ Taps Fibre-Optic Cables for Secret Access to World's Communications{{spaced ndash}} Exclusive: British Spy Agency Collects and Stores Vast Quantities of Global Email Messages, Facebook Posts, Internet Histories and Calls, and Shares Them with NSA, Latest Documents from Edward Snowden Reveal"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Retrieved June 30, 2013.</ref>{{spaced ndash}} described by [[Germany]] as "nightmarish" if true<ref>Staff (June 22, 2013). [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-23017108 "GCHQ Data-Tapping Claims Nightmarish, Says German Justice Minister"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved June 30, 2013.</ref>{{spaced ndash}} allegations that the NSA engaged in "dangerous" and "criminal" activity by "hacking" civilian infrastructure networks in other countries such as "universities, hospitals, and private businesses",<ref name="ibtimes 17 june" /> and alleged that [[regulatory compliance|compliance]] offered only very limited restrictive effect on mass data collection practices (including of Americans) since restrictions "are policy-based, not technically based, and can change at any time", adding that "Additionally, [[audit]]s are cursory, incomplete, and easily fooled by fake justifications",<ref name="ibtimes 17 june" /> with numerous self-granted exceptions, and that NSA policies encourage staff to assume the benefit of the doubt in cases of uncertainty.<ref>Clayton, Mark (June 22, 2013). {{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/doubt-nsa-searches-information-americans-123943655.html |title="When in Doubt, NSA Searches Information on Americans{{spaced ndash }} According to Newly Revealed Secret Documents, the NSA Retains Wide Discretion over Targeting Individuals for Surveillance – Including, Potentially, Americans{{spaced ndash}} Civil Libertarians Say 'It Confirms Our Worst Fears'" |accessdate=2013-06-25 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130626032506/http://news.yahoo.com/doubt-nsa-searches-information-americans-123943655.html |archivedate=June 26, 2013 }}. ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'' (via [[Yahoo! News]]). Retrieved June 30, 2013.</ref><ref>Staff (June 20, 2013). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/interactive/2013/jun/20/exhibit-a-procedures-nsa-document "Procedures Used by NSA to Target Non-US Persons: Exhibit A{{spaced ndash}} Full Document{{spaced ndash}} Top-Secret Documents Show FISA Judges Have Signed Off on Broad Orders Allowing the NSA to Make Use of Information 'Inadvertently' Collected from Domestic US Communications Without a Warrant"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Retrieved June 29, 2013.</ref><ref>Bump, Philip (June 20, 2013). [http://www.theatlanticwire.com/national/2013/06/guardian-leak-nsa-fisa-court-rules/66456 "The NSA Guidelines for Spying on You Are Looser Than You've Been Told"]. ''[[The Atlantic Wire]]''. Retrieved June 29, 2013.</ref>

== The program == [[File:PRISM logo.jpg|thumb|PRISM logo]] PRISM is a program from the [[Special Source Operations]] (SSO) division of the NSA, which in the tradition of NSA's intelligence alliances, cooperates with as many as 100 trusted U.S. companies since the 1970s.<ref name="WaPo1" /> A prior program, the [[Terrorist Surveillance Program]],<ref name="SS2" /><ref name="SS1" /> was implemented in the wake of the [[September 11 attacks]] under the [[George W. Bush Administration]] but was widely criticized and challenged as illegal, because it did not include warrants obtained from the [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court]].<ref name="SS1">{{cite web| last=Lundin|first=Leigh |title=Pam, Prism, and Poindexter| url=http://www.sleuthsayers.org/2013/07/pam-prism-and-poindexter.html |work=Spying| publisher=SleuthSayers |accessdate=January 4, 2014| date=7 July 2013 |location=Washington}}</ref><ref name="Dean1">{{cite web | author = [[John Dean|Dean, John W.]] | url = http://writ.corporate.findlaw.com/dean/20051230.html | title = George W. Bush as the New Richard M. Nixon: Both Wiretapped Illegally, and Impeachable; Both Claimed That a President May Violate Congress' Laws to Protect National Security | publisher = [[FindLaw]] | date = December 30, 2005 |accessdate=June 12, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Holtzman1">{{cite web | url = http://www.thenation.com/article/impeachment-george-w-bush | title = The Impeachment of George W. Bush | author = [[Elizabeth Holtzman|Holtzman, Elizabeth]] | work = [[The Nation]] | date = January 11, 2006 |accessdate=June 12, 2013}}</ref><ref name="ABA1">{{cite web | format = PDF | url = https://apps.americanbar.org/op/greco/memos/aba_house302-0206.pdf | title = Adopted by the House of Delegates | publisher = [[American Bar Association]] | date = February 13, 2006}}</ref><ref name="Lawyers1">Staff (February 14, 2006). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/02/13/AR2006021302006.html "Lawyers Group Criticizes Surveillance Program"]. ''[[The Washington Post]]''. Retrieved June 15, 2013.</ref> PRISM was authorized by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court.<ref name="wp_slides">{{cite news | author = Staff | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/special/politics/prism-collection-documents/ | date = June 6, 2013 |title=NSA Slides Explain the PRISM Data-Collection Program |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=June 15, 2013}}</ref>
PRISM was enabled under [[George W. Bush|President Bush]] by the [[Protect America Act of 2007]] and by the [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 Amendments Act of 2008|FISA Amendments Act of 2008]], which immunizes private companies from legal action when they cooperate with U.S. government agencies in intelligence collection. In 2012 the act was renewed by [[United States Congress|Congress]] under [[Barack Obama|President Obama]] for an additional five years, through December 2017.<ref name="Greenwald1">{{cite news| author = [[Glenn Greenwald|Greenwald, Glenn]]; MacAskill, Ewen | title=NSA Taps in to Internet Giants' Systems to Mine User Data, Secret Files Reveal – Top-Secret Prism Program Claims Direct Access to Servers of Firms Including Google, Apple and Facebook – Companies Deny Any Knowledge of Program in Operation Since 2007 – Obama Orders US to Draw Up Overseas Target List for Cyber-Attacks|work=[[The Guardian]] |url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/06/us-tech-giants-nsa-data |accessdate=June 15, 2013 | date = June 6, 2013}}</ref><ref name="McAllister">{{cite news|title=Senate Votes to Continue FISA Domestic Spying Through 2017 – All Proposed Privacy Amendments Rejected | last = McAllister | first = Neil|date=December 29, 2012|url = https://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/12/29/senate_fisa_extension_vote/ | work = [[The Register]] |accessdate=June 15, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=H.R. 5949 (112th Congress): FISA Amendments Act Reauthorization Act of 2012|url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/112/hr5949}}</ref> According to ''[[The Register]]'', the FISA Amendments Act of 2008 "specifically authorizes intelligence agencies to monitor the phone, email, and other communications of U.S. citizens for up to a week without obtaining a warrant" when one of the parties is outside the U.S.<ref name="McAllister" />
The most detailed description of the PRISM program can be found in a report about NSA's collection efforts under Section 702 FAA, that was released by the [[Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board]] (PCLOB) on July 2, 2014.<ref name="pclob">Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board, {{cite web|url=http://www.pclob.gov/library/702-Report.pdf |title=Report on the Surveillance Program Operated Pursuant to Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act|date= July 2, 2014|website=pclob.gov}}</ref>
According to this report, PRISM is only used to collect internet communications, not telephone conversations. These internet communications are not collected in bulk, but in a targeted way: only communications that are to or from specific selectors, like e-mail addresses, can be gathered. Under PRISM, there's no collection based upon keywords or names.<ref name="pclob" />
The actual collection process is done by the [[Data Intercept Technology Unit]] (DITU) of the FBI, which on behalf of the NSA sends the selectors to the US Internet service providers, which were previously served with a Section 702 Directive. Under this directive, the provider is legally obliged to hand over (to DITU) all communications to or from the selectors provided by the government.<ref name="pclob" /> DITU then sends these communications to NSA, where they are stored in various databases, depending on their type.
Data, both content and metadata, that already have been collected under the PRISM program, may be searched for both US and non-US person identifiers. These kinds of queries became known as "back-door searches" and are conducted by NSA, FBI and CIA.<ref>{{cite news|work=TechDirt|url=https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20140630/12101627734/fbi-cia-also-make-use-backdoor-searches-nsa-data-to-access-us-communications-without-warrant.shtml |title=FBI, CIA Use Backdoor Searches To Warrentlessly Spy On Americans' Communications|date= June 30, 2014}}</ref> Each of these agencies has slightly different protocols and safeguards to protect searches with a US person identifier.<ref name="pclob" />
=== Extent of the program === Internal NSA presentation slides included in the various media disclosures show that the NSA could unilaterally access data and perform "extensive, in-depth surveillance on live communications and stored information" with examples including email, video and voice chat, videos, photos, voice-over-IP chats (such as [[Skype]]), file transfers, and social networking details.<ref name="Greenwald1" /> Snowden summarized that "in general, the reality is this: if an NSA, FBI, CIA, DIA, etc. analyst has access to query raw [[SIGINT]] [signals intelligence] databases, they can enter and get results for anything they want."<ref name="ibtimes 17 june" />
According to ''The Washington Post'', the intelligence analysts search PRISM data using terms intended to identify suspicious communications of targets whom the analysts suspect with at least 51 percent confidence to not be U.S. citizens, but in the process, communication data of some U.S. citizens are also collected unintentionally.<ref name="WaPo1" /> Training materials for analysts tell them that while they should periodically report such accidental collection of non-foreign U.S. data, "it's nothing to worry about."<ref name="WaPo1" /><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/special/politics/prism-collection-documents/|title= NSA slides explain the PRISM data-collection program|date=July 10, 2013}} An annotated presentation of the NSA PRISM program as published by the Washington Post on 6 June 2013 and updated on 10 July 2013</ref>
According to ''[[The Guardian]]'', NSA had access to chats and emails on [[Hotmail.com]], Skype, because Microsoft had "developed a surveillance capability to deal" with the interception of chats, and "for Prism collection against Microsoft email services will be unaffected because Prism collects this data prior to encryption."<ref name="Greenwald2">{{cite news|author=[[Glenn Greenwald]], Ewen MacAskill, Laura Poitras, Spencer Ackerman and Dominic Rushe| title=Revealed: how Microsoft handed the NSA access to encrypted messages|work=[[The Guardian]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/11/microsoft-nsa-collaboration-user-data|accessdate=July 11, 2013|date=July 11, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Microsoft helped the NSA bypass encryption, new Snowden leak reveals|url=http://rt.com/usa/microsoft-nsa-snowden-leak-971/|publisher=Russia Today|accessdate=July 12, 2013|date=11 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/the-nsa-files|title=The NSA Files|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' | date=June 8, 2013}}</ref>
Also according to The Guardian's [[Glenn Greenwald]] even low-level NSA analysts are allowed to search and listen to the communications of Americans and other people without court approval and supervision. Greenwald said low level Analysts can, via systems like PRISM, "listen to whatever emails they want, whatever telephone calls, browsing histories, [[Microsoft Word]] documents.<ref name="SS2">{{cite web| last=Gates|first=David Edgerley| title=Through a Glass, Darkly| url=http://www.sleuthsayers.org/2013/06/through-glass-darkly.html |work=Spying| publisher=SleuthSayers |accessdate=January 4, 2014| location=Santa Fe| date=26 June 2013}}</ref> And it's all done with no need to go to a court, with no need to even get supervisor approval on the part of the analyst."<ref name="ABCNews20130728" />
He added that the NSA databank, with its years of collected communications, allows analysts to search that database and listen "to the calls or read the emails of everything that the NSA has stored, or look at the browsing histories or Google search terms that you've entered, and it also alerts them to any further activity that people connected to that email address or that IP address do in the future."<ref name="ABCNews20130728">{{cite news|last=Rea|first=Kari|title=Glenn Greenwald: Low-Level NSA Analysts Have 'Powerful and Invasive' Search Tool|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2013/07/glenn-greenwald-low-level-nsa-analysts-have-powerful-and-invasive-search-tool/|accessdate=July 30, 2013|newspaper=ABC News|date=28 July 2013}}</ref> Greenwald was referring in the context of the foregoing quotes to the NSA program [[X-Keyscore]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Glenn Greenwald |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/31/nsa-top-secret-program-online-data |title=Revealed: NSA program collects 'nearly everything a user does on the internet' |publisher=Theguardian.com |date=31 July 2013 |accessdate=January 27, 2014}}</ref>

==Responses to disclosures==
===United States government===
====Executive branch==== Shortly after publication of the reports by ''The Guardian'' and ''The Washington Post'', the United States [[Director of National Intelligence]], [[James Clapper]], on June 7, 2013 released a statement confirming that for nearly six years the government of the United States had been using large Internet services companies such as Facebook to collect information on foreigners outside the United States as a defense against national security threats.<ref name="nytsavage060613">{{cite news|author=[[Charlie Savage|Savage, Charlie]]; Wyatt, Edward; [[Peter Baker (author)|Baker, Peter]] | title=U.S. Says It Gathers Online Data Abroad|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/07/us/nsa-verizon-calls.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 6, 2013 |accessdate=June 6, 2013}}</ref> The statement read in part, "''The Guardian'' and ''The Washington Post'' articles refer to collection of communications pursuant to Section 702 of the [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act]]. They contain numerous inaccuracies."<ref name="Clapper">{{cite web |url=http://www.dni.gov/index.php/newsroom/press-releases/191-press-releases-2013/869-dni-statement-on-activities-authorized-under-section-702-of-fisa |title=DNI Statement on Activities Authorized Under Section 702 of FISA |publisher=[[Director of National Intelligence]] |date=June 6, 2013 |accessdate=June 7, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130607090238/http://www.dni.gov/index.php/newsroom/press-releases/191-press-releases-2013/869-dni-statement-on-activities-authorized-under-section-702-of-fisa |archivedate=June 7, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> He went on to say, "Section 702 is a provision of FISA that is designed to facilitate the acquisition of foreign intelligence information concerning non-U.S. persons located outside the United States. It cannot be used to intentionally target any U.S. citizen, any other U.S. person, or anyone located within the United States."<ref name="Clapper" /> Clapper concluded his statement by stating, "The unauthorized disclosure of information about this important and entirely legal program is reprehensible and risks important protections for the security of Americans."<ref name="Clapper" /> On March 12, 2013, Clapper had told the United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence that the NSA does "not wittingly" collect any type of data on millions or hundreds of millions of Americans.<ref name="Denial">{{cite news |author=Greenberg, Andy |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2013/06/06/watch-top-u-s-intelligence-officials-repeatedly-deny-nsa-spying-on-americans-over-the-last-year-videos |title=Top U.S. Intelligence Officials Repeatedly Deny NSA Spying on Americans |work=[[Forbes]] |date=June 6, 2013 |accessdate=June 7, 2013}}</ref> Clapper later admitted the statement he made on March 12, 2013 was a lie,<ref name="nytinfrastructure">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/01/us/job-title-key-to-inner-access-held-by-snowden.html|title=Job Title Key to Inner Access Held by Snowden |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 30, 2013|author=[[Scott Shane|Shane, Scott]]; [[David E. Sanger|Sanger, David E.]] |accessdate=June 30, 2013}}</ref> or in his words "I responded in what I thought was the most truthful, or least untruthful manner by saying no."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dni.gov/index.php/newsroom/speeches-and-interviews/195-speeches-interviews-2013/874-director-james-r-clapper-interview-with-andrea-mitchell|publisher=NBC News|title=TRANSCRIPT OF ANDREA MITCHELL'S INTERVIEW WITH DIRECTOR OF NATIONAL INTELLIGENCE JAMES CLAPPER|date=2013-06-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150908174404/http://www.dni.gov/index.php/newsroom/speeches-and-interviews/195-speeches-interviews-2013/874-director-james-r-clapper-interview-with-andrea-mitchell|archivedate=September 8, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
On June 7, 2013 U.S. President [[Barack Obama]], referring to the PRISM program{{Citation needed|reason=The source does not reference the PRISM program by name.|date=February 2014}} and the NSA's telephone calls logging program, said, "What you've got is two programs that were originally authorized by Congress, have been repeatedly authorized by Congress. Bipartisan majorities have approved them. Congress is continually briefed on how these are conducted. There are a whole range of safeguards involved. And federal judges are overseeing the entire program throughout."<ref name="nytobama060713">{{cite news |author=[[Charlie Savage|Savage, Charlie]]; Wyatt, Edward; [[Peter Baker (author)|Baker, Peter]]; Shear, Michael D. |title=Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/08/us/national-security-agency-surveillance.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 7, 2013 |accessdate=June 7, 2013}}</ref> He also said, "You can't have 100 percent security and then also have 100 percent privacy and zero inconvenience. You know, we're going to have to make some choices as a society."<ref name="nytobama060713" /> In separate statements, senior Obama administration officials (not mentioned by name in source) said that Congress had been briefed 13 times on the programs since 2009.<ref name="nytobama060813">{{cite news |author=Weisman, Jonathan; [[David E. Sanger|Sanger, David]] |title=White House Plays Down Data Program|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/09/us/politics/officials-say-congress-was-fully-briefed-on-surveillance.html?smid=tw-share&_r=0|newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 8, 2013 |accessdate=June 8, 2013}}</ref>

described as "an internal government computer system used to facilitate the government's statutorily authorized collection of foreign intelligence information from electronic communication service providers under court supervision, as authorized by Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) (50 U.S.C. § 1881a)."<ref name="Fact Sheet">{{cite web |archivedate=June 11, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="Clapper2">{{cite web The fact sheet was withdrawn from the NSA's website around June 26.<ref>Miller, Greg; Nakashima, Ellen (June 25, 2013). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-fact-sheet-on-surveillance-program-pulled-from-web-after-senators-criticism/2013/06/25/afe95d9e-ddda-11e2-b797-cbd4cb13f9c6_story.html "NSA Fact Sheet on Surveillance Program Pulled from Web After Senators' Criticism"]. ''[[The Washington Post]]''. Retrieved July 2, 2013.</ref>
In a closed-doors Senate hearing around June 11, FBI Director [[Robert Mueller]] said that Snowden's leaks had caused "significant harm to our nation and to our safety."<ref name="Mueller" /> In the same Senate NSA Director Alexander defended the program.{{elucidate|date=July 2013}} Alexander's defense was immediately criticized by Senators Udall and Wyden, who said they saw no evidence that the NSA programs had produced "uniquely valuable intelligence." In a joint statement, they wrote, "Gen Alexander's testimony yesterday suggested that the NSA's bulk phone records collection program helped thwart 'dozens' of terrorist attacks, but all of the plots that he mentioned appear to have been identified using other collection methods."<ref name="Mueller">Staff (June 13, 2013). [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22884566 "Snowden Leaks Caused US 'Significant Harm'{{spaced ndash}} Mueller"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved July 1, 2013.</ref><ref>Press release (June 13, 2013). [http://www.wyden.senate.gov/news/press-releases/udall-wyden-call-on-national-security-agency-director-to-clarify-comments-on-effectiveness-of-phone-data-collection-program "Udall, Wyden Call on National Security Agency Director to Clarify Comments on Effectiveness of Phone Data Collection Program"]. Office of [[Ron Wyden]]. Retrieved July 1, 2013.</ref>
On June 18, NSA Director Alexander said in an open hearing before the House Intelligence Committee of Congress that communications surveillance had helped prevent more than 50 potential terrorist attacks worldwide (at least 10 of them involving terrorism suspects or targets in the United States) between 2001 and 2013, and that the PRISM web traffic surveillance program contributed in over 90 percent of those cases.<ref>Gerstein, Josh (June 18, 2013). [http://www.politico.com/story/2013/06/nsa-leak-keith-alexander-92971.html "NSA: PRISM Stopped NYSE Attack"]. ''[[Politico]]''. Retrieved July 1, 2013.</ref><ref name="waponumbers">{{cite news|last=Nakashima|first=Ellen|title=Officials: surveillance programs foiled more than 50 terrorist attacks|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/officials-surveillance-programs-foiled-more-than-50-terrorist-plots/2013/06/18/d657cb56-d83e-11e2-9df4-895344c13c30_story.html|newspaper=Washington Post|date=June 18, 2013}}</ref><ref name="nprnumbers">{{cite news|last=Chang|first=Ailsa|title=Secret Surveillance Credited with Preventing Terror Acts|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/06/19/193347739/secret-surveillance-credited-with-preventing-terror-acts |publisher=[[NPR]]|date=June 19, 2013 |accessdate=July 1, 2013}}</ref> According to court records, one example Alexander gave regarding a thwarted attack by al Qaeda on the New York Stock Exchange was not in fact foiled by surveillance.<ref>{{cite news |title=NSA Claim of Thwarted NYSE Plot Contradicted by Court Documents|url=http://abcnews.go.com/m/story?id=19436557 |date=June 19, 2013 |publisher=ABC News |accessdate=July 13, 2013}}</ref> Several senators wrote Director of National Intelligence Clapper asking him to provide other examples.<ref>{{cite web |title=Udall, Bipartisan Group of Senators Seek Answers from DNI Clapper on Bulk Data Collection Program |url=http://www.markudall.senate.gov/?p=press_release&id=3542 |date=June 28, 2013 |accessdate=July 13, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130708003807/http://www.markudall.senate.gov/?p=press_release&id=3542 |archivedate=July 8, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
U.S. intelligence officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, told various news outlets that by June 24 they were already seeing what they said was evidence that suspected terrorists had begun changing their communication practices in order to evade detection by the surveillance tools disclosed by Snowden.<ref name="starr-cnn-2013-6025">[[Barbara Starr|Starr, Barbara]] (June 25, 2013). [http://security.blogs.cnn.com/2013/06/25/terrorists-try-changes-after-snowden-leaks-official-says "Terrorists Try Changes After Snowden Leaks, Official Says"]. ''Security Clearance'' (blog of [[CNN]]). Retrieved June 29, 2013.</ref><ref name="wapochanges">{{cite news|last=Nakashima|first=Ellen|last2=Miller|first2=Greg|title=U.S. Worried About Security of Files Snowden Is Thought to Have|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/us-officials-worried-about-security-of-files-snowden-is-thought-to-have/2013/06/24/1e036964-dd09-11e2-85de-c03ca84cb4ef_story.html |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=June 24, 2013 |accessdate=June 29, 2013}}</ref>
====Legislative branch==== In contrast to their swift and forceful reactions the previous day to allegations that the government had been conducting surveillance of United States citizens' telephone records, Congressional leaders initially had little to say about the PRISM program the day after leaked information about the program was published. Several lawmakers declined to discuss PRISM, citing its top-secret classification,<ref name="waposilence">{{cite news|last=Blake|first=Aaron|title=Congress All But Silent on Surveillance of Internet Records|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2013/06/07/congress-all-but-silent-on-surveillance-of-internet-records/|publisher=''Post Politics'' (blog of ''[[The Washington Post]]'') |date=June 7, 2013 |accessdate=June 16, 2013}}</ref> and others said that they had not been aware of the program.<ref>{{cite news|last=Everett|first=Burgess|last2=Sherman|first2=Jake|title=Republican Lawmakers: NSA Surveillance News to Me|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/06/republicans-nsa-surveillance-92418.html|work=[[Politico]] |date=June 7, 2013 |accessdate=June 16, 2013}}</ref> After statements had been released by the President and the Director of National Intelligence, some lawmakers began to comment:
Senator [[John McCain]] (R-AZ) *June 9, 2013 "We passed the Patriot Act. Senator [[Susan Collins]] (R-ME), member of Senate Intelligence Committee and past member of Homeland Security Committee *June 11 "I had, along with Joe Lieberman, a monthly threat briefing, but I did not have access to this highly compartmentalized information" and "How can you ask when you don't know the program exists?"<ref name="npr061113">{{cite news|last=Chang|first=Ailsa|title=What Did Congress Really Know About NSA Tracking|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/itsallpolitics/2013/06/11/190742087/what-did-congress-really-know-about-nsa-tracking|publisher=[[NPR]] |date=June 11, 2013 |accessdate=June 16, 2013}}</ref>

Representative [[Mike Rogers (Michigan politician)|Mike Rogers]] (R-MI), a Chairman of the [[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence]]. *June 9 "One of the things that we're charged with is keeping America safe and keeping our civil liberties and privacy intact.
