{{Other uses|Willey house (disambiguation){{!}}Willey house}} [[File:Willey House, Crawford Notch, White Mountains, New Hampshire.png|thumb|Drawing by [[W. H. Bartlett]] of the Willey House, Crawford Notch. Once the home of [[Abel Crawford|Ethan Crawford]], it later became a tourist attraction following a storm in 1826 which resulted in the deaths of the Willey family and others.]] [[File:Willey House, by Kilburn Brothers.jpg|thumb|A [[stereoscope|stereoscopic slide]] of the Willey House by [[Kilburn Brothers]], ca. 1872]]
The '''Willey House''' at [[Crawford Notch]] in the [[White Mountains (New Hampshire)|White Mountains]] of [[New Hampshire]] is associated principally with a tragedy of August 28, 1826, in which seven members of the Willey family and two other people died. Out of that event came a boost to the nascent tourism industry of the area.
== Background == The Willey House was originally known as Old Notch House and had been built in 1793. [[Abel Crawford|Ethan Crawford]] acquired it in 1823 for use as an inn to accommodate his growing business as a mountain guide, and in 1826 it was occupied by a family headed by Samuel J. Willey Jr.<ref name="bennett"/><ref name="avery">{{cite book |title=Art and the Empire City: New York, 1825–1861 |editor1-first=Catherine Hoover |editor1-last=Voorsanger |editor2-first=John K. |editor2-last=Howat |publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art |year=2000 |isbn=978-0-87099-957-4 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=j8dzQHVdv9oC&pg=PA115 |chapter=Selling the Sublime and the Beautiful: Landscape Painting and Tourism |first=Kevin J. |last=Avery |pages=115-118}}</ref><ref name="johnson">{{cite book |title=This Grand & Magnificent Place: The Wilderness Heritage of the White Mountains |first=Christopher |last=Johnson |publisher=UPNE |year=2006 |isbn=978-1-58465-461-2 |pages=55-58 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=uzBIKlqDu74C&pg=PA55}}</ref>
== 1826 disaster == Northern [[New England]] experienced a drought in the summer of 1826, which ended with the arrival of a terrific storm on the evening of August 28. Flooding followed, with the valley at Crawford Notch being one place that suffered the consequences. All but two of the bridges on the [[Toll road|turnpike]] that ran through the notch were destroyed, trees suffered a similar fate and the high sides of the valley were gouged by swollen streams and [[landslide]]s. The Willey House was a scene of desolation due to the effects of an avalanche on a mountain behind it. The house, however, had survived in an island of calm because the surging debris split either side on a low ridge and then unified again beyond it.<ref name="bennett">{{cite book |title=The White Mountains: Alps of New England |first=Randall H. |last=Bennett |publisher=Arcadia Publishing |year=2003 |isbn=978-0-73852-433-7 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xT1zt3O1kNUC&pg=PA63 |pages=63-68}}</ref>
Local residents, including [[Abel Crawford|Ethan Crawford]] and the Reverend Benjamin G. Willey, Samuel's brother, visited the house in the aftermath of the storm. It was empty, with signs that there may have been a rapid departure from it, such as unmade beds, clothes strewn around and ashes in the fireplace.<ref name="bennett"/> There was an open Bible on the table.<ref name="johnson"/> A search of the devastated area over the next few days revealed the bodies of the Willey parents, two of their daughters and two hired hands; the remains of the other three Willey children were never found.<ref name="bennett"/> Some livestock had also been killed, including those in a now-destroyed stable.<ref name="johnson"/>
There followed various theories as to what had happened, the most likely of which is that the occupants abandoned the property as the avalanche approached but in doing so, in darkness, they unwittingly put themselves in the path of it around the point where the flow reunited.<ref name="bennett"/>
== Tourist attraction == News of the disaster spread, initially through many regional newspapers,<ref name="bennett"/> and also through media such as [[Theodore Dwight (author)|Theodore Dwight's]] guidebook, ''The Northern Traveller''<!--"traveller" is spelled correctly in this instance-->.<ref name="avery"/> People began to visit the site, drawn to the scene of devastation, human tragedy and the miraculous survival of the structure itself. As well as boosting a nascent tourist industry in the area, in which the Crawford family had already been playing a significant part, it became a source of inspiration for artists and writers. The {{convert|4000|ft|m|adj=on}} peak on the western wall of the notch became known as [[Mount Willey]].<ref name="bennett"/>
Dona Brown believes that the artist [[Thomas Cole]] and other visitors, such as [[Nathaniel Hawthorne]], used the interest in the tragedy to further their careers, deliberately painting and writing about an area that had suddenly gained national attention. Ethan Crawford, too, exploited it by, for example, ensuring that the Willey House was well signposted.<ref>{{cite book |title=Inventing New England: Regional Tourism in the Nineteenth Century |first=Dona |last=Brown |publisher=Smithsonian Institution |year=2014 |origyear=1995 |isbn=978-1-58834-430-4 |pages=60, 62 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=eKhqBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT60}}</ref> The Crawfords had been directly affected by the storm, with Ethan's property suffering {{USD}}1000 of damage and his father's farm being wrecked almost beyond repair, but they were also affected in a positive manner with the subsequent influx of tourists. In 1828, Ethan began construction of a new inn, called the Notch House, at the northern end of the notch, appointing his brother Thomas to run it. The business opened in 1829 and attracted many notable people, including [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]], Hawthorne, [[Henry David Thoreau]] and [[Daniel Webster]].<ref>{{cite book |title=This Grand & Magnificent Place: The Wilderness Heritage of the White Mountains |first=Christopher |last=Johnson |publisher=UPNE |year=2006 |isbn=978-1-58465-461-2 |pages=58-59 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=uzBIKlqDu74C&pg=PA58}}</ref>
Hawthorne was inspired by the Willey tragedy to write a short story titled "[[The Ambitious Guest]]" in 1835,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Sears |first=John F. |title=Hawthorne's "The Ambitious Guest" and the Significance of the Willey Disaster |journal=American Literature |volume=54 |issue=3 |date=October 1982 |pages=354–367 |jstor=2925848 |doi=10.2307/2925848 |subscription=yes}}</ref> while Cole noted in his diary that "The site of the Willey House, with its little patch of green in the gloomy desolation, very naturally recalled to mind the horrors of the night when the whole family perished beneath an avalanche of rocks and earth."<ref>{{cite book |last=Noble |first=Louis Legrand |title=The Life and Works of Thomas Cole |publisher=Black Dome Press |year=1997 |isbn=978-1-883789-13-8 |page=66}}</ref>
Horace Fabyan, who was a merchant and a speculator in the emerging tourism industry, took control of the Willey House in 1845 and converted it into a 50-bed hotel.<ref>{{cite book |title=Inventing New England: Regional Tourism in the Nineteenth Century |first=Dona |last=Brown |publisher=Smithsonian Institution |year=2014 |origyear=1995 |isbn=978-1-58834-430-4 |page=65|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=eKhqBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT65}}</ref> Visitor interest in the effects of the disastrous storm waned over time, despite the efforts of people such as Benjamin Willey to maintain and profit by it by offering guided tours of the house for a fee. It had become old news and nature had taken it course to cover much of the scenic damage.<ref name="avery"/>
The site of the house and the landslide is now an [[Interpretation centre|interpretive center]] within [[Crawford Notch State Park]].<ref>{{Cite web| url=https://www.nhstateparks.org/visit/state-parks/crawford-notch-state-park.aspx| title=Crawford Notch State Park| publisher=NH Division of Parks and Recreation| access-date=March 12, 2018}}</ref>

'''Wing Ding''', as of 2014, has returned as an annual concert held by [[WXRX]] 104.9 FM, in Rockford, Illinois, during [[Memorial Day]] weekend, that started years ago as a chicken wing competition but later evolved into a full blown rock concert. It started in 1993. Notable bands that have played over the years are [[Shinedown]], [[Seether]], [[Saliva (band)|Saliva]], [[Breaking Benjamin]], [[Nickelback]], [[Three Doors Down]], [[Three Days Grace]], [[Buckcherry]], [[Hinder]], [[Black Stone Cherry]] and many others.
==2014== It has been announced that Wing Ding will return May 25, 2014 to the Rockford Speedway. Gates open at 11, music at noon. ===Line-Up=== *[[Alice in Chains]] *[[Black Stone Cherry]] *[[Fuel (band)|Fuel]] *[[Wayland (band)|Wayland]] *[[Queensrÿche]] *[[Adelitas Way]] *[[Cilver]]
==2009== The 16th annual Wing Ding took place on May 24, 2009 at The Bell Bowl at the [[Chicago Rockford International Airport]] in [[Rockford, IL]]. The guest host was [[Coolio]]. Wing Ding was cancelled until further notice after the 2009 show.
===Line-Up=== *[[Shinedown]] *[[Saliva (band)|Saliva]] *[[Saving Abel]] *[[Powerman 5000]] *[[Coolio]] *[[10 Years (band)|10 Years]] *[[The Parlor Mob]] *[[Halestorm]] *[[Age of Daze]] *Taddy Porter
==2008== The 15th annual Wing Ding took place on May 25, 2008 at the [[Rockford Speedway]]. [[Tone Lōc]] made a special appearance to play a few songs.
===Line-Up=== *[[Chevelle (band)|Chevelle]] *[[P.O.D.]] *[[Theory of a Deadman]] *[[Black Stone Cherry]] *[[Drowning Pool]] *[[Airbourne (band)|Airbourne]] *[[Saving Abel]] *[[The Last Vegas]]
==2007== The 14th annual Wing Ding took place on May 27, 2007 at the [[Rockford Speedway]], and was sponsored by [[Hooters]]. Early estimates show that roughly 20,000 people came to Wing Ding this year, which is roughly 8,000 more than 2006. Admission was only $10.
